text.content: HOW JUAN IMPROVED IN CLASS
Juan never listens in class. His teacher asks, “Do you pay attention, Juan?” but he looks at his phone.
He talks to Miguel, jokes with Sara, and never takes notes.
The teacher gets angry. Juan’s grades are low. His mom is worried.
She says, “You have a problem, Juan. You don’t listen in class.”
Juan promises to change. He tries to stay quiet, write in his notebook, and stop using his phone.
After some days, the teacher smiles. “You are better now,” she says.
Juan feels proud. He sees how much his discipline helps. He wants to do more.
TRAVEL PLANS TO SANTA MARTA
Sofia and her cousin Jhon want to go to Santa Marta. They like the beach and the sound of the sea.
“We have to buy a ticket,” says Sofia. “Yes, and we need a hotel,” says Jhon.
They pack a small bag with clothes and snacks. Their mom helps them plan the trip.
“You need sunscreen,” she says. At the bus station, they wait in line.
“I have to use the bathroom,” says Jhon. “We want this trip to be fun,” Sofia adds.
On the way, they laugh, listen to music, and take pictures of the mountains and sea.
PRACTICING SPORTS AND EXERCISE
Nicolás goes to the local gym after school. He loves to run and play soccer with his friends in the neighborhood.
Every afternoon, they practice before their big game on Sunday.
“It’s good for your health,” his coach says. Nicolás wants to be strong and fast, like his older brother.
He drinks water, eats fruit, and rests well. “I feel more energy now,” he says.
After running, he is full of sweat, but he smiles. His legs and arms are getting bigger—his muscles are growing.
Sports help Nicolás stay focused in school and away from problems in the barrio.
COMPARING PEOPLE IN PHOTOS
In the photo, Andrea is standing next to her cousin, Camila. Andrea is wearing a yellow shirt and smiling.
Camila is looking at her phone and holding a drink. Andrea is taller than Camila.
Camila looks younger, even though she is older. They both wear jeans, but Camila’s are ripped.
Andrea’s hair is curly and short, while Camila has long, straight hair.
Camila wears glasses, but Andrea doesn’t. “Who’s the girl on the left?” asks their aunt.
“That’s Camila,” says Andrea. “She looks different in every picture.” They laugh.
Comparing photos helps Andrea see how her family changes with time.
HOW TO GET FROM ONE PLACE TO ANOTHER
Carlos needs directions to his job interview. He asks a man, “Which way to the bus station?”
The man says, “You should take the 60B route, but you must leave now—there’s traffic.”
Carlos checks the map on his phone and sees a faster route if he walks.
He thinks, “I could avoid delays if I go by foot.”
A lady nearby says, “My advice is: don’t wait for the bus—walk three blocks and turn left.”
Carlos follows the advice, arrives early, and feels ready.
“You must be smart in this city,” he tells himself. Getting there the right way matters.
SCHEDULE TIME FOR STUDIES AND WORK
Valeria has to wake up at 5 a.m. every day. She needs to prepare breakfast, finish school tasks, and help at her family’s bakery.
Her assistance to mom starts at 7 a.m., and she finishes by noon. Then she must go to school.
She brings her study materials and lunch. “I need to make a better schedule,” she says.
In the afternoon, she studies and finishes homework. At night, she tries to sleep early.
“You must find balance,” her mom says. So, Valeria writes a weekly plan.
She learns to prioritize time: family, school, work.
Life in the barrio is not easy, but she manages it with strength.
